subsection.title: Linear Maps
subsection.p: We will say that T: {\mathbb R}^2 \to {\mathbb R}^2 is an invertible linear map if we can find a second linear map S such that T \circ S = S \circ T = I, where I is the identity transformation. In terms of matrices, this means that we can find a matrix S such that TS = ST = I, where I = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}. is the 2 \times 2 identity matrix. We write T^{-1} for the inverse matrix of T. It is easy to check that the inverse of T = \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{pmatrix} is T^{-1} = \frac{1}{\det T} \begin{pmatrix} d & - b \\ -c & a \end{pmatrix}.

statement.p: A linear map T is invertible if and only if \det T \neq 0.

proof.p: If \det T = 0, then there are infinitely many nonzero vectors {\mathbf x} such that T {\mathbf x} = {\mathbf 0}. Suppose that T^{-1} exists and {\mathbf x} \neq {\mathbf 0} such that T {\mathbf x} = {\mathbf 0}. Then {\mathbf x} = T^{-1} T {\mathbf x} = T^{-1} {\mathbf 0} = {\mathbf 0}, which is a contradiction. On the other hand, we can certainly compute T^{-1}, at least in the 2 \times 2 case, if the determinant is nonzero.

subsection.title: Changing Coordinates
subsection.p:
Suppose that we consider a linear system {\mathbf y}' = (T^{-1} A T) {\mathbf y} where T is an invertible matrix. If {\mathbf y}(t) is a solution of , we claim that {\mathbf x}(t) = T {\mathbf y}(t) solves the equation {\mathbf x}' = A {\mathbf x}. Indeed,
{\mathbf x}'(t) & = (T {\mathbf y})'(t) & = T {\mathbf y}'(t) & = T( (T^{-1} A T) {\mathbf y}(t)) & = A (T {\mathbf y}(t)) & = A {\mathbf x}(t).
We can think of this in two ways.
A linear map T converts solutions of {\mathbf y}' = (T^{-1} A T) {\mathbf y} to solutions of {\mathbf x}' = A {\mathbf x}.
The inverse of a linear map T takes solutions of {\mathbf x}' = A {\mathbf x} to solutions of {\mathbf y}' = (T^{-1} A T) {\mathbf y}.
We are now in a position to solve our problem of finding solutions of an arbitrary linear system \begin{pmatrix} x' \\ y' \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix}.

activity.title: Distinct Real Eigenvalues and Transformation of Coordinates

introduction.p: Consider the system of linear differential equations d\mathbf x/dt = A \mathbf x, where A = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \amp -1 \\-1 \amp 2 \end{pmatrix}.

statement.p: Find the eigenvalues of A. You should find distinct real eigenvalues \lambda and \mu.
Find eigenvectors \mathbf v_1 and \mathbf v_2 for the eigenvalues \lambda and \mu, respectively.
Construct the 2 \times 2 matrix T = (\mathbf v_1, \mathbf v_2) and find T^{-1}.

subsection.title: Complex Eigenvalues
subsection.p:
Suppose the matrix A = \begin{pmatrix} a \amp b \\ c \amp d \end{pmatrix} in system {\mathbf x}' = A {\mathbf x} has complex eigenvalues. In this case, the characteristic polynomial p(\lambda) = \lambda^2 - (a + d)\lambda + (ad - bc) will have roots \lambda = \alpha + i \beta and \overline{\lambda} = \alpha - i \beta, where
\alpha \amp = \frac{a + d}{2} \beta \amp = \frac{\sqrt{4bc - (a - d)^2}}{2}.
The eigenvalues \lambda and \overline{\lambda} are complex conjugates. Now, suppose that the eigenvalue \lambda = \alpha + i \beta has an eigenvector of the form \mathbf v = {\mathbf v}_ 1 + i {\mathbf v}_2, where \mathbf v_1 and \mathbf v_2 are real vectors. Then \overline{\mathbf v} = {\mathbf v}_ 1 - i {\mathbf v}_2 is an eigenvector for \overline{\lambda}, since A \overline{\mathbf v} = \overline{A \mathbf v} = \overline{\lambda \mathbf v} = \overline{\lambda} \overline{\mathbf v}. Consequently, if A is a real matrix with complex eigenvalues, one of the eigenvalues determines the other.

statement.p: If \lambda = \alpha + i \beta is an eigenvalue of a real matrix A with \beta \neq 0 and eigenvector the form {\mathbf v}_ 1 + i {\mathbf v}_2, where {\mathbf v}_1 and {\mathbf v}_2 are real vectors, then the vectors {\mathbf v}_1 and {\mathbf v}_2 are linearly independent.

proof.p:
If {\mathbf v}_1 and {\mathbf v}_2 are not linearly independent, then {\mathbf v}_1 = c {\mathbf v}_2 for some c \in \mathbb R. On one hand, we have A ({\mathbf v}_ 1 + i {\mathbf v}_2) = A (c {\mathbf v}_2 + i {\mathbf v}_2) = (c + i) A {\bf v}_2. However,
A ({\mathbf v}_ 1 + i {\mathbf v}_2) & = (\alpha + i \beta) ( {\mathbf v}_ 1 + i {\mathbf v}_2) & = (\alpha + i \beta) ( c + i) {\mathbf v}_2 & = ( c + i) (\alpha + i \beta) {\mathbf v}_2
In other words, A {\mathbf v}_2 = (\alpha + i \beta) {\mathbf v}_2. However, this is a contradiction since the left-side of the equation says that we have real eigenvector while the right-side of the equation is complex. Thus, {\mathbf v}_1 and {\mathbf v}_2 are linearly independent.

statement.p: Let A be a real matrix with eigenvalue \lambda = \alpha + i \beta, where \beta \neq 0. If {\mathbf v}_ 1 + i {\mathbf v}_2, is an eigenvector for \lambda, then there exists a matrix T such that T^{-1} AT = \begin{pmatrix} \alpha & \beta \\ - \beta & \alpha \end{pmatrix}.

proof.p:
Since {\mathbf v}_1 + i {\mathbf v}_2 is an eigenvector associated to the eigenvalue \alpha + i \beta, we have A ( {\mathbf v}_1 + i {\mathbf v}_2) = (\alpha + i \beta) ({\mathbf v}_1 + i {\mathbf v}_2). Equating the real and imaginary parts, we find that
A {\mathbf v}_1 & = \alpha {\mathbf v}_1 - \beta {\mathbf v}_2 A {\mathbf v}_2 & = \beta {\mathbf v}_1 + \alpha {\mathbf v}_2.
If T is the matrix with columns {\mathbf v}_1 and {\mathbf v}_2, then
T {\mathbf e}_1 & = {\mathbf v}_1 T {\mathbf e}_2 & = {\mathbf v}_2.
Thus, we have (T^{-1} A T) {\mathbf e}_1 = T^{-1} (\alpha {\mathbf v}_1 - \beta {\mathbf v}_2) = \alpha {\mathbf e}_1 - \beta {\mathbf e}_2. Similarly, (T^{-1} A T) {\mathbf e}_2 = \beta {\mathbf e}_1 + \alpha {\mathbf e}_2. Therefore, we can write the matrix T^{-1}A T as T^{-1} AT = \begin{pmatrix} \alpha & \beta \\ - \beta & \alpha \end{pmatrix}.

subsection.p: The system {\mathbf y}' = (T^{-1} AT ) {\mathbf y} is in one of the canonical forms and has a phase portrait that is a spiral sink (\alpha \lt 0), a center (\alpha = 0), or a spiral source (\alpha \gt 0). After a change of coordinates, the phase portrait of {\mathbf x}' = A {\mathbf x} is equivalent to a sink, center, or source.

example.p:
Suppose that we wish to find the solutions of the second order equation 2x'' + 2x' + x = 0. This particular equation might model a damped harmonic oscillator. If we rewrite this second-order equation as a first-order system, we have
x' & = y y' & = - \frac{1}{2} x - y,
or equivalently \mathbf x' = A \mathbf x, where A = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ - 1/2 & - 1 \end{pmatrix}. The eigenvalues of A are - \frac{1}{2} \pm i \frac{1}{2}. The eigenvalue \lambda = (1 + i)/2 has an eigenvector \mathbf v = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -1 + i \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \end{pmatrix} + i \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}, respectively. Therefore, we can take T to be the matrix T = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \amp 0 \\ -1 \amp 1 \end{pmatrix}. Consequently, T^{-1} A T = \begin{pmatrix} 1/2 & 0 \\ 1/2 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ -1/2 & -1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 0 \\ -1 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -1/2 & 1/2 \\ -1/2 & -1/2 \end{pmatrix}, which is in the canonical form \begin{pmatrix} \alpha & \beta \\ - \beta & \alpha \end{pmatrix}. The general solution to {\mathbf y}' = (T^{-1} A T) {\mathbf y} is {\mathbf y}(t) = c_1 e^{-t/2} \begin{pmatrix} \cos(t/2) \\ -\sin(t/2) \end{pmatrix} + c_2 e^{-t/2} \begin{pmatrix} \sin(t/2) \\ \cos(t/2) \end{pmatrix}. The phase portrait of {\mathbf y}' = (T^{-1} A T) {\mathbf y} is given in .

subsection.title: Repeated Eigenvalues
subsection.p: Now suppose that A has a single real eigenvalue \lambda. Then the characteristic polynomial of A is p(\lambda) = \lambda^2 - (a + d)\lambda + (ad - bc), then A has an eigenvalue \lambda = (a + d)/2.

proposition.statement: If A has a single eigenvalue and a pair of linearly independent eigenvectors, then A must be of the form A = \begin{pmatrix} \lambda & 0 \\ 0 & \lambda \end{pmatrix}.

proof.p: Suppose that {\mathbf u} and {\mathbf v} are linearly indeendent eigenvectors for A, and let T be the matrix whose first column is {\mathbf u} and second column is {\mathbf v}. That is, T {\mathbf e}_1 = {\mathbf u} and T{\mathbf e}_2 = {\mathbf v}. Since {\mathbf u} and {\mathbf v} are linearly independent, \det(T) \neq 0 and T is invertible. So, it must be the case that AT = (A {\mathbf u}, A {\mathbf v}) = (\lambda {\mathbf u}, \lambda {\mathbf v}) = \lambda ({\mathbf u}, {\mathbf v}) = \lambda IT, or A = \begin{pmatrix} \lambda & 0 \\ 0 & \lambda \end{pmatrix}.

subsection.p:
In this case, the system is uncoupled and is easily solved. That is, we can solve each equation in the system
x' \amp = \lambda x y' \amp = \lambda y
separately to obtain the general solution
x \amp = c_1 e^{\lambda t} y' \amp = c_2 e^{\lambda t}.

statement.p: Suppose that A has a single eigenvalue \lambda. If \mathbf v is an eigenvector for \lambda and any other eigenvector for \lambda is a multiple of \mathbf v, then there exists a matrix T such that T^{-1} A T = \begin{pmatrix} \lambda & 1 \\ 0 & \lambda \end{pmatrix}.

proof.p:
If {\mathbf w} is another vector in {\mathbb R}^2 such that {\mathbf v} and {\mathbf w} are linearly independent, then A \mathbf w can be written as a linear combination of \mathbf v and \mathbf w, A {\mathbf w} = \alpha {\mathbf v} + \beta {\mathbf w}. We can assume that \alpha \neq 0; otherwise, we would have a second linearly independent eigenvector. We claim that \beta = \lambda. If this were not the case, then
A \left( {\mathbf w} + \left( \frac{\alpha}{\beta - \lambda} \right) {\mathbf v} \right) \amp = A {\mathbf w} + \left( \frac{\alpha}{\beta - \lambda} \right) A {\mathbf v}
\amp = \alpha {\mathbf v} + \beta {\mathbf w} + \lambda \left( \frac{\alpha}{\beta - \lambda} \right) {\mathbf v} \amp = \beta {\mathbf w} + \alpha \left(1 + \frac{\lambda}{\beta - \lambda} \right) {\mathbf v} \amp = \beta {\mathbf w} + \alpha \left( \frac{\beta - \lambda + \lambda}{\beta - \lambda} \right) {\mathbf v} \amp = \beta \left( {\mathbf w} + \left( \frac{\alpha}{\beta - \lambda} \right) {\mathbf v} \right) and \beta would be an eigenvalue distinct from \lambda. Thus, A {\mathbf w} = \alpha {\mathbf v} + \lambda {\mathbf w}. If we will let {\mathbf u} = (1/ \alpha) {\mathbf w}, then A {\mathbf u} = {\mathbf v} + \frac{\lambda}{\alpha} {\mathbf w} = {\mathbf v} + \lambda {\mathbf u}. We now define T {\mathbf e}_1 = {\mathbf v} and T{\mathbf e}_2 = {\mathbf u}. Since
AT \amp = A\mathbf u + A \mathbf v = \mathbf v + \lambda \mathbf u + \lambda \mathbf v T\begin{pmatrix} \lambda & 1 \\ 0 & \lambda \end{pmatrix} \amp = T (\lambda \mathbf e_1) + T \mathbf e_1 + T (\lambda \mathbf e_2) = \mathbf v + \lambda \mathbf u + \lambda \mathbf v,
we have T^{-1} A T = \begin{pmatrix} \lambda & 1 \\ 0 & \lambda \end{pmatrix}. Therefore, {\mathbf x}' = A {\mathbf x} is in canonical form after a change of coordinates.

example.p:
Consider the system \mathbf x' = A \mathbf x, where A = \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 1 \\ -4 & 1 \end{pmatrix}. The characteristic polynomial of A is \lambda^2 - 6 \lambda + 9 = (\lambda - 3)^2, we have only a single eigenvalue \lambda = 3 with eigenvector \mathbf v = (1, -2). Any other eigenvector for \lambda is a multiple of \mathbf v. If we choose \mathbf w = (1, 0), then \mathbf v and \mathbf w are linearly independent. Furthermore, A \mathbf w = \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ - 4 \end{pmatrix} = 2 \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} + \lambda \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} = 2 \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} + 3 \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}. So we can let \mathbf u = (1/2) \mathbf w = (1/2, 0). Therefore, the matrix that we seek is T = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \amp 1/2 \\ -2 \amp 0 \end{pmatrix}, and T^{-1} A T = \begin{pmatrix} -1/2 & 2 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 1 \\ -4 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \amp 1/2 \\ -2 \amp 0\end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 1 \\ 0 & 3 \end{pmatrix}. From , we know that the general solution to the system \begin{pmatrix} dx/dt \\ dy/dt \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 1 \\ 0 & 3 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} is \mathbf y(t) = c_1 e^{3t} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} + c_2 e^{3t} \begin{pmatrix} t \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}. Therefore, the general solution to \begin{pmatrix} dx/dt \\ dy/dt \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 1 \\ -4 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} is
\mathbf x(t) \amp = T \mathbf y(t) \amp = c_1 e^{3t} T \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} + c_2 e^{3t} T \begin{pmatrix} t \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \amp = c_1 e^{3t} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} + c_2 e^{3t} \begin{pmatrix} 1/2 + t \\ -2t \end{pmatrix}.
This solution agrees with the solution that we found in .

subsection.p: In practice, we find solutions to linear systems using the methods that we outlined in Sections. What we have demonstrated in this section is that those solutions are exactly the ones that we want.

ul.li: A linear map T is invertible if and only if \det T \neq 0.
A linear map T converts solutions of {\mathbf y}' = (T^{-1} A T) {\mathbf y} to solutions of {\mathbf x}' = A {\mathbf x}.
The inverse of a linear map T takes solutions of {\mathbf x}' = A {\mathbf x} to solutions of {\mathbf y}' = (T^{-1} A T) {\mathbf y}.

A change of coordinates converts the system {\mathbf x}' = A {\mathbf x} to one of the following special cases, \begin{pmatrix} \lambda & 0 \\ 0 & \mu \end{pmatrix}, \begin{pmatrix} \alpha & \beta \\ -\beta & \alpha \end{pmatrix}, \begin{pmatrix} \lambda & 0 \\ 0 & \lambda \end{pmatrix}, \begin{pmatrix} \lambda & 1 \\ 0 & \lambda \end{pmatrix}.

exercise.p: Explain what a change of coordinates is.
Given a 2 \times 2 linear system, what are the possible types of solutions?
